aboutPages.title: Atomic Protocol: The Hyperliquid of Gaming
aboutPages.subtitle: A dedicated, high-performance Layer 1 engineered specifically for betting and gaming.
aboutPages.body:
GambleFi is exploding, but the infrastructure powering it is stuck in the past. Most platforms today are just applications trying to run on congested, general-purpose blockchains that weren't built for high-speed gaming.

Atomic Protocol changes the game. We are building the "Hyperliquid of Casinos"—a dedicated, high-performance Layer 1 blockchain engineered specifically for betting. By building the chain from the ground up for this one purpose, we deliver a trading and gaming experience that is faster, fairer, and more reliable than anything else on the market.

aboutPages.title: The Problem
aboutPages.subtitle: Most crypto casinos still rely on "trust me" infrastructure and opaque execution.
aboutPages.body:
Most crypto casinos today are black boxes. They ask you to deposit funds into a smart contract you can't read, run by a centralized team you don't know, on a blockchain that might degrade under congestion.

Many platforms rely on federated setups where a small set of insiders control critical components like randomness and execution, which means the house can theoretically manipulate outcomes or freeze funds. Players are forced to trust the operator—defeating the core promise of crypto.

aboutPages.title: Competitor Analysis
aboutPages.subtitle: Why Atomic’s architecture, performance, and transparency beat application-layer casino networks.
aboutPages.body:
To understand why Atomic is superior, it helps to compare it to Proov Network.

Architecture: Proov is an application built on top of Solana, meaning it inherits Solana’s congestion and downtime risks. Atomic is a sovereign blockchain optimized solely for gaming throughput.

Performance: Proov is limited by Solana’s block times. Atomic is 80% faster than Solana, processing bets with the speed required for institutional-grade trading.

Transparency: Proov relies on opaque, private processes. Atomic is publicly verifiable—anyone can audit the chain in real-time to prove fairness.

aboutPages.title: High-Performance Consensus
aboutPages.subtitle: Instant validation with a BFT approach built for speed, reliability, and verifiability.
aboutPages.body:
Atomic Protocol utilizes an advanced Byzantine Fault Tolerance (BFT) consensus mechanism—the same high-performance approach used by Hyperliquid—to validate transactions instantly.

This ensures that our backend is fully transparent and immutable: from the precise millisecond a user clicks "wager" through to funds landing back in their wallet, every single step is recorded on-chain and publicly verifiable.

There are no hidden steps, no optimistic assumptions, and no waiting—just pure, unmanipulatable speed.

aboutPages.title: Provably Fair Overview
aboutPages.subtitle: Understanding Provably Fair Gaming
aboutPages.body:
Provably fair gaming represents a revolutionary approach to online gambling that ensures complete transparency and fairness. Unlike traditional online casinos where players must trust that the house isn't manipulating results, provably fair systems provide cryptographic proof that every game outcome is fair and unbiased.

Our platform uses Verifiable Random Functions (VRF) to generate game outcomes. This means that every result can be independently verified by anyone, ensuring that neither the casino nor players can manipulate the outcome after a bet is placed.

The system works by combining unpredictable blockchain data (like block hashes) with your transaction details to create a unique, verifiable random output for each game. This output is then used to determine the game result in a deterministic way that can be verified by anyone.

aboutPages.title: VRF Implementation
aboutPages.subtitle: Verifiable Random Functions
aboutPages.body:
Our casino uses ECVRF (Elliptic Curve Verifiable Random Function) with the SECP256K1_SHA256_TAI cipher suite from the vrf crate v0.2.5. This implementation provides RFC 9381 compliant cryptographic randomness with Ed25519 key management.

Each game outcome uses a VRF message constructed with SEC-4 Enhanced Chain Context binding that includes: chain ID, block height, block hash, previous app hash, block randomness, transaction hash, transaction index, wallet address, nonce, and timestamp. This ensures maximum security against replay attacks.

The VRF produces both a cryptographic proof and a deterministic output. Game results are derived using SHA256(vrf_output)[0] & 1 - even bytes = heads, odd bytes = tails. This derivation is publicly verifiable and impossible to manipulate.

Technical Specification:

• VRF Implementation: ECVRF with SECP256K1_SHA256_TAI cipher suite

• Key Management: Ed25519 signing keys with persistent storage

• Message Hashing: SHA256 with RFC 9381 domain separation

• Result Derivation: SHA256 hash of VRF output, least significant bit

• Proof Format: Base64-encoded ECVRF proof bytes

• Security Level: 128-bit security with collision resistance

aboutPages.title: Technical Implementation
aboutPages.subtitle: Technical Details
aboutPages.body:
Our provably fair system is built on CometBFT consensus with a custom ABCI (Application Blockchain Interface) application written in Rust. Each game transaction triggers VRF computation using the vrf crate v0.2.5 with ECVRF implementation.

The system uses Ed25519-based VRF keys that are persistently stored in a Sled embedded database. VRF messages are constructed using SEC-4 Enhanced Chain Context binding, combining blockchain state (block height, hash, timestamp) with transaction data (hash, wallet, nonce) for maximum security.

Game results are derived deterministically from VRF output using SHA256(vrf_output)[0] & 1. This ensures that outcomes are mathematically provable and cannot be manipulated by any party, including the casino operators.

VRF Message Construction:
SEC-4 Enhanced Chain Context Version:
VRF_MESSAGE = SHA256("MYCHAIN:VRF:SEC4:FULL:v1" || chain_context || transaction_data)
Where chain_context includes block height, hash, previous app hash, block random, and timestamp

Result Derivation:
result_hash = SHA256(vrf_output)
coin_flip = (result_hash[0] & 1) == 1 ? "heads" : "tails"

Verification Libraries:

• Rust VRF Crate: vrf = "0.2.5" with ECVRF implementation

• Ed25519 Keys: ed25519-dalek = "2.1" for key management

• Hashing: sha2 = "0.10" for SHA256, blake3 = "1.5" for block randomness

• Consensus: tower-abci = "0.12" and tendermint = "0.34"

API Response Format:
{
  "tx_hash": "3B63730078FF47BD...",
  "result": "heads",
  "vrf_proof": "base64_encoded_ecvrf_proof",
  "vrf_output": "base64_encoded_vrf_output",
  "vrf_public_key": "base64_encoded_ed25519_public_key",
  "height": 12345
}
